title: Individual Differences in the Impact of Socio-Economic Events on Health and Well-Being
abstractText:
People’s well-being, consisting of, for example, their health, happiness and overall satisfaction with life, is influenced by a variety of life events as well as changes in the society in which they live. Our programme of research will show:

  • the type of person who loses or gains the most well-being when socio-economic events take place
  • the psychological reasons as to why people’s well-being changes after such events.

We explore five key questions:

  1. Do well-being reactions to socio-economic events depend on a person’s personality characteristics prior to the event occurring?
  2. Does personality change in predictable and meaningful ways?
  3. Are people’s health and well-being affected by how much they actually earn, or how their income ranks amongst others?
  4. Do losses in income have a proportionally greater impact on well-being than an equivalent income gains?
  5. Do people have lower levels of well-being in less equal societies?

Our aim in answering these questions is to:

  • contribute new answers to old theoretical questions
  • encourage interdisciplinary collaboration in understanding the influences on well-being
  • feed into policy debates
  • suggest an increased role for psychologists to work alongside other social scientists in informing policy.
